repnme.cdata!: Algeria - Emergency Desert Locust Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Emergency Desert
            Locust Control Project in Algeria can be rated as
            satisfactory since it achieved its main objectives while
            both the Bank and Borrowers performances were deemed
            satisfactory. Due to a significantly lower than normal
            rainfall coincided with the project, far less vegetation was
            available to catalyze locust breeding. Therefore, the
            project shifted its focus to preventative measures instead.
            The changes deal mostly with cancellation of funds since
            much of it was not disbursed. Key lessons learned from this
            project are as follows: (i) In the future, with the
            improvement of the surveillance and control system (which
            has been strengthened by the project), such heavy treatments
            are unlikely to be needed. Future participating
            organizations and projects should focus more on prevention
            and early warning than on treatment. (ii) In order to ensure
            an improved prevention system at the international level,
            priority should be given to the improvement, efficient use
            and combination of recently developed complementary tools
            such as: the permanent remote sensing and field information
            system and the existing bio-model developed by PRIFAS on the
            basis of the biology of locusts. (iii) The need for improved
            international coordination in locust control programs is
            essential. (iv) Desert locust management will also require
            financing of multi-country program that will equitably
            benefit all countries of the region and (v) locust control
            activities would benefit from the use of improved and
            alternative products that have recently been developed and
            which promise to be less costly and less damaging to the environment.

repnme.cdata!: Algeria - Emergency Desert Locust Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Desert Locust Control
            Project has two main objectives.  The first is to provide
            urgent assistance in support of Algeria's national
            locust control program.  The second is to further reinforce
            the existing surveillance and warning systems, enabling the
            country to better predict locust activity and movements,
            thus facilitating planning and implementation of future
            control programs in situations of both plague and recession.
            The early warning activities financed under the project will
            also benefit other countries in the region. The project will
            essentially consist of disaster prevention rather than
            disaster relief and the dealing with an existing emergency.
            The project consists of the following components:  (a) three
            locust control campaigns over the period February/March 1994
            to January 1995; (b) further strengthening national desert
            locust control capabilities by increasing the existing stock
            of vehicles, spare parts for vehicles, laboratory equipment
            for pesticide analysis, and health kits for the operators;
            (c) for prospection purposes, provision of small
            meteorological and mobile telecommunication equipment,
            including air to ground receivers and 10 hand-held global
            positioning systems; (d) provision of short-term consultancy
            and technical documentation to strengthen the capabilities
            of National Institute for Plant Protection in the safe
            handling, application and storage of pesticides, and
            disposal of pesticides and pesticide containers; and (e)
            training in locust prospection methods, pesticide handling,
            phytopharmacy and in pesticide-related environmental protection.
